review.title: A Hypercat-enabled Semantic Internet of Things Data Hub: Technical Report
review.abstract: An increasing amount of information is generated from the rapidly increasing number of sensor networks and smart devices. A wide variety of sources generate and publish information in different formats, thus highlighting interoperability as one of the key prerequisites for the success of Internet of Things (IoT). The BT Hypercat Data Hub provides a focal point for the sharing and consumption of available datasets from a wide range of sources. In this work, we propose a semantic enrichment of the BT Hypercat Data Hub, using well-accepted Semantic Web standards and tools. We propose an ontology that captures the semantics of the imported data and present the BT SPARQL Endpoint by means of a mapping between SPARQL and SQL queries. Furthermore, federated SPARQL queries allow queries over multiple hub-based and external data sources. Finally, we provide two use cases in order to illustrate the advantages afforded by our semantic approach.

sections.heading: 7.2 City Concierge
sections.text: CityVerve is an IoT demonstrator project based in Manchester, UK, which was launched in July 2016 with a two-year focus on demonstrating the performance of IoT applications for smart cities. One of the uses of the CityVerve project, City Concierge, aims to increase the acceptance of walking and cycling as the preferred mode of travel in Greater Manchester. Currently, Greater Manchester lacks integrated, consistent route finding services that can be accessed through a variety of media, including digital and print. City Concierge aims to develop an urban user interface for the city region, integrating transport and visitor services that allow users to make informed decisions about the way they travel.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, the semantic enrichment of the BT Hypercat Data Hub was presented. Specifically, the BT Hypercat Ontology was introduced, which forms the basis for translating existing data into an RDF representation. In addition, the BT SPARQL Endpoint was implemented as a set of SPARQL endpoints and an additional endpoint, called the Federated SPARQL Endpoint, was provided to enable the execution of federated queries. In addition, several examples of federal queries illustrate how the BT Hypercat Data Hub can be connected to the LOD Cloud. Finally, two use cases illustrate the enhanced functionality of the system, highlighting the benefits of semantic enrichment. Future work will include further semantic enrichment of the implemented system. In particular, the current support for SPARQL queries can be extended to enable GeoSPARQL queries to provide direct access to spatial information currently available in the Data Hypercat Hub.
